review_title: Poor management. Clear favoritism. Toxic work environment especially micro management
job_title: Crisis Intervention Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros: They pay well in crisis and there’s bonuses
cons: Management is abysmal. HR clearly doesn’t care and will gaslight and invalidate if brought valid concerns. Employees in my unit were not listened to and left out of important issues. Bosses didn’t help us when busy and ignored many of us like we were beneath them. I am so much less stressed now that I don’t work there anymore. They didn’t even throw me a birthday party like they do everybody else ESPECIALLY management.

review_title: Fantastic company and amazing, caring people

job_title: School Based Therapist in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Pretty good pay for the job
cons: Not a great work environment

pros: Work with some awesome people
cons: Supervisor and upper management don't care about your workload or mental health. They brow beat you every chance they can get for you to do more work

pros: Paid time off and sick pay

pros:
Benefits
Ability to advance

 poor work life balance.

pros: Good company to work for. Strong teamwork which is needed for job.
cons: Low pay and extreme stress. The system is broken and not all company fault.

review_title: The mission no longer aligns with org actions
pros:
- Benefits
- Flexibility
- Pay is better than most social service positions
cons: Upper management (i.e anyone not working directly in client care) is a nightmare. Workers are treated poorly and our mental health concerns are met with "you have 8 free therapy sessions through EAP." The mental health issues from many workers stem from McNabb being completely driven by funding and thus, productivity. We got into this line of work to help people, and we can barely do that with the workload. Then, we're held responsible for any failures with clients as if we even have the time to help. Productivity expectations are unrealistic and I have asked every supervisor, all the way up to the director of my program, for numbers that prove their expectations are attainable. Each time I have been told "we don't have those numbers." They know they are wrong, but they don't care. They have had so many workers in crisis in the time that I have been in this program and all we can do is talk to one another because our crises go unheard by management. They don't care about employees, they don't care about clients, and they don't care about the Knoxville community. They care about a bottom line and ensuring they have a paycheck at the end of the day. We continue to have the same issues in our department and the supervisors continue to blame the workers instead of seeing that their productivity expectations are unattainable and inhumane. Ableism is rampant from the mental health providers to the supervisors. They talk about our clients in such a dehumanizing and derogatory way. I'm only still with the organization because I have bills to pay. Helen Ross McNabb would be ashamed if she could see the way Jerry runs things today.

pros: Very flexible hours for PRNs. Team leads are great. Some good benefits and bonus incentives for full-time employees.
cons: PRNs are paid significantly lower wages for the same education and performance expectations of FT employees.

pros:

pros: I have worked at Helen Ross McNabb for almost a year now and have been nothing but pleased with how the company takes care of their employees. There is also room for growth so you are not stuck in one place. I am so happy that I decided to work for HRMC and plan to stay here for a very long time.
cons: Honestly, I have not had any cons so far and have worked in two different positions within the company.

review_title: A great place for people who care about improving the lives of others
pros: The people you work with really care about helping others and that creates a good team, and overall positive environment.  The people in leadership are positive and supportive.   They really appreciate their employees and have an annual Longevity Awards program where they celebrate all employees, especially those that have been with the agency 5 years or more.  It's a good place to work if you are highly motivated to help others.  Everyone here is trained and encouraged to do their best to provide the best services available.  Management leads by example. There is a positive workplace expectation that you do your best, going above and beyond for the clients and each other.  It's an agency that people can move up in, and many do.  I have been promoted twice and was allowed to take a less demanding position once when experiencing some burnout.
cons: Like anywhere else, you might come across a coworker or supervisor that is somewhat negative or difficult.  It's not often and they usually get weeded out so to speak, but that can happen anywhere.  Working in mental health and social services in general often times is not easy.   It's a nonprofit so the pay is average for the field.

job_title: Master Level Clinician in Knoxville, TN
pros: Good benefits and gained a lot of clinical experience
cons: Stressful, heavy workload, office politics

pros: McNabb's benefits are decent for a single payer, Administration makes an effort to hear staff concerns, and most needs are addressed in time.  The company has experienced significant growth since I've been here and continues to grow.  There's lots of opportunity for lateral movement. Lots of great people work here (it takes special people to work in this field, and many of them are just plain fun.)
cons: The mental / emotional labor is significant.  Self Care is very important.  Salaries vary depending on positions, but there can be significant differences between similar positions (Ex Working direct care with children vs adults) that don't seem to be fair.  Upward growth is limited unless you have a Masters Degree.  Some of the administration appears disconnected with front line staff experiences.  The company is less transparent than it used to be as far as new programs opening and new opportunities for existing staff.

review_title: Absolutely! I would advise anyone to seek HRMC!
pros:
I have a boss that's like no other! Her initials are PC. She has everlasting patience and always seems to know the best route to take to deal with every situation! 
Also, for any adult or child with a mental health diagnosis should try HRMC before trying anywhere else. The juvenile and adult centers work diligently to help individuals reach and maintain their goals. HRMC employees understand that each person's life is different and that treatment has to be different for each one that partakes in our programs.
cons: The only downside I can find for working for HRMC is the friendships I make along the way. I know it sounds silly, but it is hard to maintain a professional distance when you care about members so deeply. If you love case management, counseling, or just being a nighttime monitor, it can be hard to let go of clients when they want to move on. You just want to keep them under your wing and protect them always.

pros: I really enjoy that there is such a therapeutic work environment in the program I work in. I feel like my supervisors genuinely care about me and my well being, and they do what they can to support me. I felt like there was a  well paced onboarding process when I joined, and my supervisor was diligent in making sure I was properly trained on all the duties listed in my job description. I have found that all my co-workers are hardworking and caring, and everyone seems to embrace the mission of the center "Improving the lives of the people we serve". I also really appreciated the thorough training you get the first week of work.
cons: The pay is a little lower for some jobs, but it's because the center is a non-profit organization, so they don't have the funds to match some competitive rates.

review_title: Largest mental health provider in East Tennessee
pros: If you want a job in mental health, McNabb will likely be a company you will consider because they have a huge portion of the market in East Tennessee--especially the Knoxville area. They have about 50 job openings on any given day. It is easy to get hired by McNabb.
cons: Two negatives go hand-in-hand with a job at McNabb: low pay and an unreasonable work load. Burnout is high, especially among people who work there just to have a job but don't really have a calling to work with the mentally ill. Those who desire to work the field do their best; there are many good people working there! But the morale is at a constant low due to always having too much on your plate.

review_title: Best Non-Profit I have worked for yet
pros:
Helen Ross McNabb is a non-profit organization. Typically with a non-profit salary is low, but when I was hired by this organization, I was offered a significantly higher pay increase for doing the same job I was already doing for another non-profit. 
HRM offers many benefits outside of health insurance. They seem to always be offering discounts at different businesses, which include gym memberships, weight loss clinics, offer free flu shots and wellness clinics, and a variety of other things. 
At first, I was very hesitant about switching jobs, but am so glad that I made the change. Although I enjoyed my job at the other non-profit, it seems that HRM has so much more to offer. The staff is friendly and communicative, the administration is more than willing to help with any questions you may have.
cons: I currently have no Cons

review_title: Great Company, Competitive Pay and Amazing Benefits
pros: Most of the management staff work at the HRMC with the purpose of propagating the vision of the company which is to "improve the lives of the people we serve". Management that oversee supervisors and direct front line staff are wonderful and supportive. The pay is competitive, the benefits offered make up for the salary and the environment overall is nurturing and warm.
cons: The administrative staff can tend to be disconnected from the front line staff. Overall the culture is positive though.

job_title: Accounts Payable Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Knowing that no matter what position you hold at HRMC you are one of many working together as a team to help improve the lives of others.
Amazing coworkers that are like family to me. Too many to list, but HRMC has some of the best benefits that I have ever received throughought my 34 year career of working various other jobs.
cons: Hearing the real life stories & struggles that some of our clients have faced in their past, present and/or will be facing in their future weighs heavy on my heart. It can be very stressful at times, but the pros of working for HRMC far outweigh the cons.

review_title: Corporate billing office is led not by respect or leadership, but by fear
pros:
Everyone has their own office and since it's non-profit, there is no accounting for office supplies or billing mistakes. Closing the books is a breeze, numbers are made up so you can balance which makes for an easy close.
The vision and purpose of the company is solid and clinical staff do a great job, especially considering the little pay they receive.
cons:
You can either make up the numbers above or you can be fired. The director makes it very clear if you don't do what you are told, even when you know it's wrong, you will be fired. Everyone that has stood up to her has been terminated and replaced with someone who is willing to, in her words, "play dumb." 
The pay is minimal. The constant fear of fraud hangs over your head.

review_title: Pretty great but room to grow
pros: flexible work week, people are passionate about the job, good coworkers, good health benefits, good supervisor, most major holidays off, generous bonus was given out this year, good community recognition, feel like your making a difference, plenty of opportunities for positions changes horizontally, opportunities for PRN work
cons: emotionally draining, time off  takes a long time to build unless you've been here 5 years,  pay for degree positions needs to be higher, not a lot of vertical job changes (promotions) available.

review_title: 3 years and different positions - same management issues.
pros: Great Mission. Most employees actually believe in the mission and are sincerely trying to improve people's lives. Awesome benefits to full time employees. Great training programs for CE. Great company to gain experience or acquire hours for licensure. Large client base. Clearly serves the community positively.  Very organized and streamlined orientation process. Thorough pre-screening process for employees.
cons:
Disclaimer* This is a well-meaning company from the top down and frequently attempts to improve itself and its employees. The company merged with local community services across the state and grew quicker than it could manage. If you read this years from now, these issues may have been eliminated.*

It takes forever to get hired because the hiring managers have more work than they know what to do with. You have to be committed to working here or unlucky in your other employment pursuits. It took two months from application to orientation for me.  

Low Pay and high workloads throughout the spectrum of different positions. 
Preference given to degrees in education instead of competence and capability to perform the job. 
 Management is frequently hired based on license and education in mental health instead of education and experience in management.  The result is a high frequency of tolerance for sub-par performances and a lack of accountability.  
Employees already exploit the management issues and are frequently found talking about their feelings with managers and wasting productive time. The lack of management skills and standard operating procedures literally leads to employees being completely unaware of processes and even services of different departments. This ultimately leads to a disconnected and inefficient work environment.

pros: The frontline staff is kind and helpful. The upper management do what they can every day to improve the working lives of thier employees. The benefits are amazing and the work is unbelievably rewarding.
cons: The compay has been growing faster than the buildings can expand so sometimes it can be a little cramped and hard to find a parking space.

pros: I love working for HRMC. Especially given we are a nonprofit with tight budgets, the organization feels steady and stable. We regularly receive cost of living increases in salary and bonuses. There is plenty of infrastructure in place to support us doing our jobs. The work is rewarding, feeling like you're impacting the lives of the people we are serving.
cons: Social work always comes with it's challenges. The company is wonderful, but in general, keeping up with the work and meeting the needs of those served is challenging.

review_title: Most rewarding nursing position in my career.
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Knoxville, TN
pros: 12 hour shifts create more days off to spend with family. Insurance and benefits are comparable. Retirement plan is better than any around! Rewarding to work with our clientele. Unit staff all work as a cohesive team to meet the goals of the clients. Enjoy going to work!
cons: Working holidays and weekends however that goes along with nursing in general. A Pro is working at a place you love and look forward to going even the con isn't negative.

review_title: Pros & Cons of Helen Ross McNabb
job_title: Case Manager in Lenoir City, TN
pros: As a case manager you set your own schedule.
cons: The company has unrealistic expectations for case managers and doesn't value their employees or clients. There's little room for advancement, someone would need to retire or a new position be created for real chances at advancement.

pros: great benefits, supportive team and upper management, open communication and decent pay considering this is a non-profit agency.
cons: I have not found a Con for working here. I have been here for 5 years and I plan on retiring with this company. I have never felt so supported and appreciated in a workplace.

review_title: Supportive supervisors, growth opportunity for excellent staff members, and worthy mission.
pros: You get to help others, do meaningful work, and get valuable human service experience with a stable, ethical company. Great benefit package especially time off and health insurance.
cons: Pay may be average due to not for profit status as may be expected. The stress of working with mentally ill persons may not be manageable by some.

job_title: Mental Health Tech in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Flexible scheduling,  prns can choose to accept or decline shifts
cons: Disorganized, Most of the homes the clients live in house around 9 clients each. They are in horrible shape, mold, old falling apart. Meds are misplaced and ill organized. There is only one house that stays stocked with food. It is pitiful the lack of food for these people . I would not let any of my family stay here if they were mentally ill.

review_title: Would be better with higher pay
pros:
Good experience
Typically good people to work with besides a few 
That's pretty much it
Flexible scheduling for yourself typically.
cons:
Over load of clients 
Low pay 
Some people throw the whole work dynamic off by attitude towards others 
Low hopes for growth

review_title: Why I'm Running Out the Door First Chance I Get
job_title: Adult IST Case Manager in Knoxville, TN
pros:
-Helping disadvantaged population:
Most clients are very low-income and disabled

-Little supervision:
No micromanaging in this position; however I can't speak to any administrative positions. 

-Great benefits, very cheap if you're single

-Promotes from within

-Volunteer opportunities, mostly at community events or at fundraisers
cons:
THE WORK:

When you first start, no matter the positon, you spend a week doing worthless 'module' training which consists of you sitting in a dark, cold, smelly, windowless computer lab for 8 hrs a day clicking through slides and videos looking like they were created in the early 90s. Note: you have to redo these every year you work here. 

Week 2 as Case Manager: this is when you realize how incredibly disorganized your direct supervisors are. They throw a bunch of forms at you that you will use in the field, take 5 minutes to explain them, and then make you shadow other case managers. The case managers will try to explain things to you but it's not going to help until you just do it on your own. 

Once you work on your own, you quickly learn that 80% of your work will be chauffeurring clients. We case managers joke about how we're a "glorified taxi service". In other words, you'll immediately begin to wonder why this job requires a degree. Additionally, there are copious amounts of paperwork, so you need to manage your time very wisely (I will address this later).

The work, while rather simple, is very high stress because you'll have clients constantly calling to complain calling because they want you to do somethi g for them that is not in your job description. Then when you tell them you can't they'll yell at you. This job reqires a lot of patience and a high tolerance for stress. Several coworkers have had breakdowns, so this position is not for everyone.

SCHEDULE/HOURS:
This position requires 40 hrs/week. Ideally you would work 8 to 5 with an hour for lunch, however, often you'll be busy with clients so you won't take a lunch, but you can be off work by 4 if that's the case. Management does not like you to skip lunch so you can't do this every day, but a few times a week is acceptable.  
 Management stresses to not work a second over 40 hours a week, if you do you will be reprimanded. This is the worst part of the job and I've seen many people be fired for this:
You're required to meet with clients 90 hours ("productivity") a month which, with the driving time, waiting on clients, and making calls will take up about 120 hours of your month. The paperwork takes a lot of time so you'll either lose productivity hours or you'll inevitably work overtime.  Most of us work overtime amd don't record it because you get reprimanded. So this is the lose-lose situation: your fired for working overtime or your fired for not getting your work done. The management has created a moral dilemma for their employees where we're all scared we'll lose our jobs if we don't omit the overtime we've worked on our timesheets.  

PAY:
Typically you're paid about 27,000 annually. Be aware, though, the job is advertised as salary on the posting and by the interviewer. This position IS NOT salary. You are paid $13 to $14 hourly so don't be fooled.  

OTHER CONS:

- your car will be ruined by all the driving you do (you do get reimbursed for mileage though)
- bed bugs, lice, fleas can be picked up from clients and you'll be stuck with infestation in your car or home and Helen Ross will not pay for bed bug treatment if it gets in your home
-Company is very political, people who are less quailified but friends with managers get the promotions.  Employees who are less liked on a personal basis by managers get singled out and disciplined, which is why you have to lay-low, keep your head down, and not ever speak up about problems with job or you will be fired.

review_title: A Place to make a difference
pros: As an organization HRMC is very serious about providing the best service possible for the client.  Mental Health Services are a precarious balance of keeping the doors open and providing needed services; HRMC never loses sight of the latter while being quite serious about remaining financially able to take care of it's employees.
cons:
High Stress; in spite of a lot of support Mental health services are not an easy gig.
Pay is in line with other similiar organizations, but your definitely not going to get rich.

review_title: Transition from Child and Family to Helen Ross
job_title: Education Enrichment Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros: Because it is a larger organization, we were able to serve more clients with a wider variety of needs.
cons: Because of the transition, there was a general lack of communication and sense of uncertainty from many about their future within the organization.

pros: Flexible schedule, supportive management, all those employed in upper management began as case managers, utilizes a team approach to meet the needs of those at risk.
cons: Underpaid - but it's a not-for-profit, high paperwork volume - we do bill insurance so this is to be expected

cons: No cons for me.  I would recommend anyone interested in a career with mental health clients be aware it can be strenuous emotionally and physically so employees must maintain self care and a positive attitude.

pros: Working 1:1 with clients and with a group, working with adults with co-occurring disorders, being able to work as a great team
cons: Scheduling was very flexible where you could work 1st shift and 3rd shift in a week.

review_title: I hear things have changed at Gateway..

pros:

pros: Flexible schedule, not stuck in an office all day
cons: Way too much paperwork to get done in a timely manner, opportunities for advancement are few

pros: Co-workers, some rewarding work with clients
cons: Awful management, politics, terrible compensation, those who lie and cheat get promoted, while others who work hard get burnt out.

job_title: Health Link Care Coordinator in Knoxville, TN

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bean Station, TN

cons: Not the greatest pay- benefits are s/w high.

pros: Raise every year, bonus each year, good benefits like PTO, sick time. They also promote within

job_title: Clinical Program Assistant in Memphis, TN

pros: they can be flexible

pros: Good pay and benefits. good co workers

review_title: Improving the lives of the people we serve....

understanding members  in  HR

pros: It's a great company to work for! Good pay, wonderful benefits! You feel appreciated!

pros: Decent pay, Great benefits, flexible schedule

job_title: Business Office in North Knoxville, TN
pros: The flexibility in the hours/days you can work
